instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damaged With Some Heating and Low Resistance to Ground
threads.message:
I fixed WD <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> by jumping wires to replace corroded vias/traces from <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> to <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR>, and replaced <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR>.
<CHIP>U7971</CHIP> was nicked and J5815 was destroyed with its traces from prior pry damage. Replaced them both. Near them were some corroded components that I replaced.
<TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR> was corrosion underneath it, removed it and cleaned everything. Not sure if I replaced it, forgot to take note and the laptop sat for some time waiting for a new battery.
Now the laptop runs almost normally except that it charges extremely slow and discharges quickly, and I felt some heat coming from <TRANSISTOR>Q7635</TRANSISTOR>, L630.
Tested the line between them and I got 13 OHM resistance to ground. I narrowed this low resistance to <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>. Is this normal in any way? Never worked on this line before and have no idea!
Note: <CHIP>U7971</CHIP> which I had replaced has nothing to do with it. Removing it doesn't change resistance to ground of <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damaged With Some Heating and Low Resistance to Ground
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damaged With Some Heating and Low Resistance to Ground
threads.message: I will, but even with <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR> removed, I have that same low resistance between <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> and ground = 13OHM. Is it normal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damaged With Some Heating and Low Resistance to Ground
threads.message: Absolutelly normal..... ohm´s law, low voltage/high current = low resistance

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damaged With Some Heating and Low Resistance to Ground
threads.message:
[QUOTE="aprendiz, post: 1459"]Replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR> first....[/QUOTE]

I replaced it from an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. It is not the same marking on the chip, but it is the same as per the schematics...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damaged With Some Heating and Low Resistance to Ground
threads.message:
[QUOTE="aprendiz, post: 1461"]Absolutelly normal..... ohm´s law, low voltage/high current = low resistance[/QUOTE]

I have to close shop. Will test tomorrow the charging and see if it changed after replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR>.
And so the lesson is I don't have to hunt for a short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> because it will normally have low resistance? 
If yes, reminds me of the first time I thought I found shorted caps on the line going under the iPhone CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damaged With Some Heating and Low Resistance to Ground
threads.message:
OK this is becoming interesting.
Before I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR>, it was charging very slowly.
I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR> and got "battery not charging" and no orange light, only green. 3V42 is present.
As I said before, I noticed heat next to <CHIP>U9600</CHIP>, and I noticed that if I tap <CHIP>U9600</CHIP>, fans stop from spinning (still with green light on charger), then they start again.
Should I reball or reflow? I am afraid some silicone/glue crap will go underneath it.
And should this resolve my issue of no charging?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damaged With Some Heating and Low Resistance to Ground
threads.message: <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> has nothing to do with anything other than screen flicker/distortion. Are you sure we're looking at <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damaged With Some Heating and Low Resistance to Ground
threads.message:
Yes I am sure it is <CHIP>U9600</CHIP>. By the time you replied I had reballed it.
I can confirm also that it was not causing the interruptions because it is still doing it, though less. Heating may have reflowed something although I can't see what?!
LD was around <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> and I found what seem to be oxidized pads on the chip, and the image did flicker sometimes so I hope I did not do useless work.
Before replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR> as suggested by apprentiz, I had slow charging and orange light. After replacing "no charging" and only green light.
First time I worked on it, via from <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> to <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> was corroded and I had to jump. So I poked around and found missing line between Pin 4 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR> and Pin 16 of ISL. Must have failed during last rework. After jumping <SIGNAL>CHGR_BGATE</SIGNAL> the laptop is back to charging and orange light, BUT still restarts if I poke next to <CHIP>U9600</CHIP>. Not sure if this is something I need to address?
I am going to test speed of charging now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damaged With Some Heating and Low Resistance to Ground
threads.message:
- Charging normally, this is solved.
- Wasted time on <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> but I'd like to think I may have saved it from near future failure since the pads were oxidized.
- Still some heat near <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> and poking there still restarts laptop! Otherwise working normally.
I'm handing it back to client having solved what he brought it for: started with LD leading to no charge then no boot when lines got corroded.. That's solved.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damaged With Some Heating and Low Resistance to Ground
